Award.AwardTitle: Spectral Analysis of Brown Carbon Secondary Organic Aerosol from the IR to the UV
Award.AbstractNarration:
Carbonaceous atmospheric aerosols, including black and brown carbon, impact climate through altering the optical properties of the atmosphere, and also by themselves undergoing further photochemical oxidation, in a poorly understood manner. This in turn may alter their own optical properties. The overall goal of this work is to improve the scientific basis for quantitatively modeling organic aerosol radiative effects. The results have application in remote sensing data retrieval algorithms, improving the reliability of radiative transfer models for aerosol and climate forcing calculations, and better understanding the impact of brown carbon (BrC) aerosol may have on atmospheric chemistry and climate.

In previous work, University of Iowa researchers developed specialized laboratory optical capabilities to measure dust aerosol optical properties over the UV-Vis-IR spectrum, and have explored how physicochemical processing of aerosols alters those properties. Here they will further extend their experimental capabilities with a highly sensitive technique, cavity ring down laser spectroscopy (CRDS). This will be used to precisely measure the optical properties of the brown carbon (BrC) fraction of ambient and laboratory mimics of organic aerosols, across the visible and the mid-IR spectral range. How those properties may change as a result of UV photochemical processing will be further studied.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Light absorbing particles in the atmosphere associated with carbonaceous material such as “brown carbon” (BrC) are particularly important in climate modeling. Accurately modeling the net radiative forcing contribution of BrC aerosol requires specific information about aerosol optical properties such as the refractive index. The optical properties depend on the particle composition, which, in turn, depends on how the aerosol was formed and subsequently processed through atmospheric chemistry. The project goal was to carry out laboratory measurements of the optical properties of selected BrC aerosol materials, to determine how the properties change with chemical aging, and to correlate the changes with variations in chemical composition.

The aqueous phase reaction of ammonium sulfate (AS) with methylglyoxal (MG) yields BrC products that absorb in the visible. This pathway is potentially important because of the atmospheric abundance and high water solubility of MG and the ubiquitous presence of deliquesced ammonium salt aerosol. We carried out measurements on a range of optical and physical properties of BrC aerosol formed through this pathway. Changes in the BrC chemical composition with reaction time are clearly evident in the results from ultraviolet-visible (UV-vis) absorption spectroscopy and micro-Raman scattering experiments. However, the optical constants for the BrC aerosol formed through this reaction pathway (as determined through infrared absorption spectra and the light scattering and extinction measurements at 403 nm) show no measureable changes when compared to unreacted ammonium sulfate. This observation suggests that BrC formed through this reaction pathway may play a limited role in climate forcing.

Aerosols generated from aqueous samples of humic material standards are often used as proxies for organic particulates found in the atmosphere, including “humic-like substances” (HULIS) that arise naturally from decomposing organic matter. To test the suitability of these standards as proxies for atmospheric BrC we measured the optical constants at a wavelength of 403 nm for aerosols formed from six humic material standards (3 humic acid and 3 fulvic acid samples). We find clear differences in the retrieved aerosol optical constants between the fulvic acid samples with low absorption indices (average k ~ 0.037), and the more strongly absorbing humic acid samples with higher absorption indices (average k ~ 0.170). By comparing chemical and elemental compositions of the materials with measured optical constants, we found a strong correlation with the aromatic content. Comparison with predicted absorption values for a range of organic aerosol from both field and laboratory measurements suggest that an appropriate fulvic acid, like Suwannee river fulvic acid, might serve as a suitable proxy for atmospheric humic-like substances (HULIS) while a corresponding humic acid, like humic acid sodium salt, might be used as a proxy for less soluble, more carbonaceous aerosol such as that from biomass burning, in investigations of radiative forcing. However, the large range of absorbing organic aerosol in the atmosphere requires that details of the absorption strength and the spectral dependence must be carefully considered to reach quantitative conclusions when using humic material proxies.

Results from these studies help to provide a scientific basis for more accurate modeling of BrC radiative effects in the atmosphere.  This, in turn, can better inform public policy discussions regarding the potential importance of BrC aerosol in climate forcing.

The research also has clear and potent societal benefits through engaging students in the STEM disciplines.  Two post-doctoral fellows and three graduate students have been active in various phases of the work. The project offers excellent opportunities for these students and post-docs to develop as independent scientists and to prepare them to serve as next generation scientific leaders.
